reviewText: Basic Instinct 2 is indeed a guilty pleasure. Absolutely trashed by the critics upon its cinematic release a few months ago, the film disappeared pretty quickly, but it's a lot more fun than you might expect, and Sharon Stone as the Machiavellian best-selling crime novelist Catherine Tramell really is a pleasure to watch - although it's pretty obvious the actress is trying to fight the hands of time.Some viewers might consider that Stone is a getting a little too long in the tooth to play this character, but I thought that at forty-eight her age - and her lurid type of sagginess - actually contributed to the authenticity of her character. She spends most of the movie spouting lines loaded with sexual insinuation, casually sitting around her pent-house London apartment in heels, tight skirt and full makeup waiting for Dr. Michael Glass (a very hot David Morrissey) to arrive.The story is convoluted and not that believable and it tries to skewer the original movie whilst also presenting a fresh take on Catherine's murderous escapades. However, it's all good, sordid and garish fun. As the movie begins, Catherine is driving a fast sports car through the deserted streets of London, upon her climax; she crashes it into the river resulting in the death of a major sports star.Roy Washburn (David Thewlis), a Scotland Yard detective with a bad attitude is convinced that Tramell, who managed to swim to the surface, was responsible for the man's death. She's got the best defense attorney her massive wealth can buy, so Washburn calls in top shrink Michael Glass (Morrissey) to run a forensic psychoanalysis that could nail her.Of course, Doctor and subject form an attachment, with Glass becoming as sexually obsessed with Tramell. He's warned by Dr. Milena Gardosh (Charlotte Rampling) to stay away, but he just can't help himself. As the murder count piles up, Glass becomes increasingly captivated by "risk addiction" and we never know for sure who is murdering whom.Sharon Stone is good as Catherine, probably because she knows the part so well, and lets face it - no other actress would dare to play the character. But the real discovery is David Morrissey as Michael Glass. His performance is much better than the film really deserves. He pulls off a multifaceted blend of conceit and scarcely concealed wrath whilst still remaining sympathetic. Thewlis is good too, nabbing all the best lines and sporting a bizarre Welsh accent.One notable aspect of this movie is the slick and polished production design. In fact, the movie reminded me a little of the brilliant mid-eighties Kim Basinger film 9  Weeks, which has many of the same qualities.  Director Michael Caton-Jones has imbued his film a kind of trendy and urban architectural symbolism. Everything is slick and faux designed and London as never looked so fashionable and glamorous.Glass' office is in one of London's new phallic steel-and-glass buildings, and the City's trendiest clubs and most modernized districts provide the bulk of the film's locations. These images are among the film's sharpest elements. The sex scenes are also quite well done - and are surprisingly hot; there's no doubt that Morrissey has the body to bear it all - although perhaps the lovely Ms. Stone shouldn't be showing as much as she does.While Basic Instinct 2 obviously lacks the impact of its prequel, as a sexy and stylish thriller, it's still worth watching - and most importantly - it's entertaining. Although there are many mind-messes, red herrings and elementary guilt transferals involving murderous and closeted obsessions, particularly in the third act, the performances, particularly Morrissey's, ultimately make the film worth sitting through. Mike Leonard July 06.

reviewText: Well the American public is at it again. Every year we seem to get a small handful of movies where the public really goes overboard and declares a movie the worst of all-time. Think back over the last five years or so. We had "Town & Country" (remember that one?), "The Brown Bunny", "Swimfan" they even overhype certain movies and call them masterpieces. It always seems to be one extreme or the other. And this is all happening again with "Basic Instinct 2".The film has opened to a rather disappointing box-office. It grossed a little more than three million dollars. It already is scored as one of the worst 250 movies of all time on IMDB.com. And for what? If this is the worst movie you have ever seen, you my friend have made some great cinematic choices. You must be watching Ingmar Bergman and Akiria Kurosawa all day.Is "Basic Instinct 2" a bad movie? Well, in a way yes. It's bad in the sense the screenplay and the directing and some of the acting lacks a certain logic, but, it's not an offensively bad movie. In other words, if someone tells you they didn't like it, fine, but, I'm surprised at the violent reaction this film is getting. That is simply uncalled for and is a clear case of people over-reactingI wouldn't want to go over much of the plot for this film because I would rather you see it on your own and discover everything for yourself. So if you're looking for a plot description just give me my unhelpful vote and go on to the next review, because I'm not going to reveal much in way of plot.The story takes place in London where Catherine David Tramell (Sharon Stone) is accused of murder when she and a soccer star get into a car accident. Their car runs over a bridge and into a river. She escapes he doesn't. A cop, Roy Washburn (David Thewlis) knows that Catherine is guilty but doesn't have enough evidence to book her. But in the meantime a doctor, (David Morrissey) is sent to give her an examination to decide whether or not she is mentally sane or not. And from that moment on we are in a nice game of cat and mouse between everyone!As I said the movie had some flaws, I won't deny it, but rather I embrace them. I went along with the movie and tried my hardest to enjoy it. And there are elements to enjoy. The best thing about the movie is Sharon Stone. Her performance in a classic, but more vulgar and explicit, version of a femme fatale. In every scene Stone had my attention. She is both sexy and trashy at the same time.Besides Stone you have some other good actors involved. It was very nice seeing Charlotte Rampling playing another doctor, but sadly she wasn't given much of a part. I wish there were more scenes with her character. And David Thewlis is quite good as well. It's a meaty part that could have gotten lost in the shuffle with another actor but Thewlis makes the part memorable. I'll bet you'll remember his character when you leave the movie.So what exactly is wrong with "Basic Instinct 2" then? Well I felt as if the movie was jerking us around a bit too much. Everything was all set-up and very little execution. Near the end of the film it wants to be something of a brainteaser but never really comes to a satisfying conclusion. Does this mean there will be a part 3? I don't know. And one could also agrue, despite my praise for Stone, that the movie is trying too hard to be sexy and alluring. You may have a point but here is where things get a bit confusing. Either you go along with the dialogue and accept it, or you begin to question everything and say it's all implauseable. I'm a pretty good sport so I went along with the film and gave it a fighting chance. Which is more than a lot of other people are doing.So should you go see this movie or not? Granted there are a lot of better movies to watch, especially with many of them coming out on DVD, but if you're looking for a guilty pleasure on a Friday or Saturday night I think "Basic Instinct 2" may good a good idea. Because again, if for any reason you'll simply want to see Sharon Stone's performance.Bottom-line: Not bad but not great either. It's a kind of guilty pleasure that requires you to shut off your brain. Has good moments and good actors but the weak script and sloppy directing does get in the way. Still it's up to you if you want to see this.
summary: Go With Your "Instinct" On This One

reviewText: Yes, the ice pick wielding seductress Catherine Tramell is back, and those hoping for a campy foray into "Showgirls" territory are bound to be disappointed. Sadly, despite all the right ingredients, "Basic instinct 2" plays it fairly straight. One keeps hoping the movie to cut loose and become hilariously trashy, but it actually tries to tell a solid story, with middling results. Sharon Stone is just fine; one really can't imagine anyone else playing this role, and she's great fun to watch. No one but Stone can throw a wicked look or be as playfully seductive as she can, too bad the script doesn't help her out. The movie becomes a dreary bore whenever Sharon Stone is not onscreen. Among the many problems, the dialogue isn't as ripe and juicy as one would expect from such a potential campfest. David Morrissey, in the Michael Douglas role, is too stiff and bland to carry the weight of a hot male lead, and setting the movie in London doesn't do much good either. The movie goes on and on with meandering plot twists and a decidedly sad lack of spark and oomph. Surprisingly, the movie actually does wrap up nicely, thanks entirely to Stone's enthralling portrayal, but what a long, painful slog to get to that point! Basically, "BI2" feels more like a wasted opportunity, and the sad final nail in the coffin of Catherine Trammel.

reviewText: People say Sharon Stone "still" looks good "for her age" in this film.I suppose she does.  She's what, 47, 48?  Way to go.  If that's our single criterion for rating "Basic Instinct 2," hey, four stars - two each for her personal trainer and her Botox therapist.I was a big fan of the original, which, if indisputably preposterous, was at least entertaining.  Stone's commando leg-crossing may have made her a star, but her actual acting performance as the sexy psychotic socialite serial killer Catherine Tramell was what really carried the film.  The fact that she was able to breathe creative life into the corniest dialogue ever hacked up by Joe Ezsterhaus stands as a greater testament to her craft (from the technical point of view) than her critically-acclaimed work in "Casino."  And the film itself rocked along, never allowing you to dwell on any of its compounded absurdities for very long before distracting you with another one.To top it off, it was beautifully shot by Paul Verhoeven in a sort of sepia-toned homage to Hitchcock's "Vertigo."  If the script was Cinemax B-movie trash, the production was old-Hollywood glamour at its most glamourous.14 years later...enter the sequel.  I'd heard rumors from time to time, but when I actually saw the trailer for "BI2" - starring, yes, Sharon Stone, who was already saying a decade ago that she was getting too old to reprise the role - I could scarcely suspend my disbelief.  Still, having enjoyed the original as I did, I figured I'd give it a shot.  The early negative reviews didn't deter me.  Actually they rather encouraged me, considering that they sounded so similar to the critical lampoonings the first film received.Unfortunately, "BI2" is barely a "sequel" at all.  Sharon Stone is the only player from the first film to condescend to participate in the second - which might've been OK, considering that she really IS the "brand."  The problem is, she seems to have completely forgotten how to have fun with the character, and consequently, she's not so much fun to watch anymore.  I (for one) don't blame it on her age - no, she doesn't look exactly the same as she did in 1992, but her performance back then didn't depend on the fact that she was in her 30's.  What's missing is the "charm," oddly enough.  Catherine Tramell is a sociopath, a cold-blooded killer, a "risk addict;" but she's also supposed to be charming - so charming, in fact, that you keep forgeting about her fondness for icepicks until she rips one out from beneath the sheets.  But in "BI2," she's become a creature (or caricature) of pure icy malevolence, without the slightest admixture of magnetism to make her tolerable, let alone seductive.  She glares, she growls, she prowls around like a jaded drag queen in her "monied tramp" wardrobe - and you simply can't force yourself to give a damn about any of it.  At least, I can't.Of course, the plot once again revolves around every other character in the movie being ineluctably fascinated by her; but her utter lack of charisma reduces the whole thing to a farce.  They all become entangled in her web purely because they're supposed to.  She "seduces," and they "give in," and who cares.  It's all mechanical and contrived.  None of the actors seem to be taking it seriously, or even subtly playing up the joke.  Meanwhile Stone's Tramell's contempt for everyone and everything she encounters is probably the single relatable aspect of her performance.  You get why she considers them to be dull and dispensable; you just can't imagine why they stick around for their punishment.(By the way, it seems a bit of a reach to claim that "BI2" is some kind of intended campy masterpiece.  It's a bad movie, and I'm sure everybody involved knew it was going to be a bad movie, but I don't get the impression that they were actually shooting for laughs.  I don't think they knew what they were shooting for.  Then again, the scene in which Catherine wistfully weilds her icepick as if in nostalgic contemplation of prior homicides is admittedly more hilarious than the entire run of "Scary Movies.")The film is very slickly produced - you know, like a Volkswagen commercial.  It's all polished veneers under krieg lights, set to techno music.  But again, it has absolutely none of the warmth and sensuality of the first "BI."  The story takes place in London this time, and the film effectively conveys the feeling of a draft under the door on a rainy day.  Even the "sex" scenes (surprisingly few, considering) are bathed in a cold, clinical, bluish-grey ambience that looks like it would be better suited to light bodies in a morgue on "CSI."  The obligatory "full frontal" nude scene doesn't involve sex at all.  But none of the actors manifest the slightest semblence of sexual chemistry with each other in the first place, so it actually makes sense that the production follows suit.No, I can't say that I recommend "Basic Instinct 2," even for laughs.  It's simply boring.  Too bad for Sharon Stone - this project was clearly all about the "empowerment" of getting naked at 48, which is fine, but she should've made sure there was some sort of actual movie there in the background.  Otherwise, better to just pose for Playboy.

reviewText: "Basic Instinct 2" is not as terrible as some reviews suggest it is, but it is definitely not a great film either.  It's neither good nor bad.  It's nothing.  Literally.  The movie supplies nothing we haven't seen in any dozen random episodes of "Law and Order" or mystery movies of the week.  It is dull, drab and typical.  That describes the script, the setting and the performances.Sharon Stone seems to be game to pull out all the stops again, but she's the only one.  As a result, she is way over the top, chewing scenery and over-acting - precisely the way she did in the first film.  The difference is, in the first film, everyone else was in on the joke and just as game for going over the top - as if they knew they were playing characters from some alternate reality where people actually act the way they do and the things that happened to them were actually possible.  And thanks to Joe Eszterhaz's insanely dopey script (the examples of bad dialogue are too many to list), even the things the characters said led us to believe we were watching something from a world the mirrored ours, but actually seemed to walk its way out of a pulp novel from some heavy-breathing author (Catherine Wolf perhaps).Of course, the first "Basic Instinct" wasn't all that good either (we just all remember it as being good simply because much of the movie was memorable - brutal ice pick murders, graphic scenes, the infamous "leg crossing" scene, lurid script, and nourish direction by Paul Verhoven), and watching it now, it is even more of a howler but, if you were willing to play along, it was at least satisfying in all the elements it promised to supply.  Actually, it delivered and then some.  Which is why it remains fun and watchable, despite moments and dialogue that make you want to burry your head in your lap out of sheer embarrassment for everyone involved (how did they do and say some of that stuff and keep a straight face).This sequel is all the things the original was not.  It does feel of this world, not just because of its setting (a drab London setting that looks more like a back lot), but because director Michael Canton-Jones does nothing with this material that resembles the Hitchcockian techniques that Verhoven used to such great effect.  The characters feel at least slightly real, and the situations are more plausible than much of what occurs in the first film, even though the events and characters in this film may seem to stretch credibility, they don't do so any more than most movies in this genre.  Nothing here is different than most movies of this genre.  This is going-through-the -motions personified.  If this didn't have the words "basic instinct" in the title, this film would be completely ignored and debued on cable.It may resemble something closer to reality, but all this is precisely what makes it such a boring procedural.  Despite its flaws, one thing no one can ever accuse the first of film of being was boring or procedural.  So we are left with a mystery thriller like every other.  Which brings us back to exactly why Stone's performance does not belong in this movie.  More accurately, the movie doesn't belong with her performance."Basic Instinct 2" is even bland on the soft-core level that most people who figured even if this movie sucks, if nothing else, they'll see some decent sex scenes.  You'd do better to flip on Cinemax after midnight than anteing up for this flick.  The sexiest scene in the film does not even involve Stone, and the scenes that do would not add up to the length (or quality) of any one of the scenes from the first film.  Stone looks good for her age, but it is obvious it has been 14 years since "Basic" 1.  The years have been good to her, but then again, so has her plastic surgeon. (Stone would probably say something like, `I've only had my boobs done,' and that's exactly what I'm talking about.  No kidding, Sharon. Did you think after spending countless films baring your breasts we wouldn't notice?  For the record, they looked better before.)The years may have been kind, but she still looks and (even more so) sounds a little foolish running through this territory again.  And this David Morrissey they have paired her up with is as dull as the rest of the film (he fits).  He seems to be a fine actor, but if you're going to call a movie "Basic Instinct 2," you need to remember the fireworks between Michael Douglas and Stone because audiences sure do.  There is nothing suspenseful, dangerous or sexy between these two.Ditto this movie.Would it really have been that hard to make another over-the-top, violent, sexy thriller like the first one?
summary: You'd think their 'basic instinct' would have been to - at the very least - entertain.

reviewText: Like any movie, Basic Instinct 2 has its pros and its cons, but because of the high camp factor of the film, it was pretty much branded as a disaster right from the start whether the critics had actually seen it or not. Granted, I just saw it for the first time some four years after its release, but having already heard the negative reviews I was bracing myself for a letdown. Plus I wasn't overly impressed with the first one, which generally is liked. But my first thought after turning it off was, "Well that wasn't so bad."That's not to say this is Oscar winning material we're dealing with here, because like I said the over-the-top performances, especially Sharon Stone's, are almost parodies of the characters established in the first film. reviewText: There is something to be said for Michael Caton-Jones' "Basic Instinct 2", and that is that one man's trash is another man's treasure.  In this turgid followup to Paul Verhoeven's original (and equally trashy) 1992 psychosexual romp, the icepick-wielding vixen, Catherine Tramell, is back and, as played by Sharon Stone, she's as flippant, horny, and, oh yes, lethal as ever.  And I'm happy to report that Catherine's trailer park sex appeal also remains intact; without an iota of class, she roars through London, decimating all of those unfortunate enough to get in her way.  It was hard, even in the original "Basic Instinct", to buy Catherine Tramell as the product of a wealthy, privileged upbringing, so undisguised was her utter, careless wantonness, her frankly stated and (apparently) insatiable appetites.  But that's what makes Catherine so much fun to watch.  A cross between Hannibal Lector and "Queer As Folk's" Brian Kinney, she's a twisted, sexed-up, very dangerous camp icon who behaves in much the same way an over-the-top male character might be expected to behave. I know people who are more appalled by her sexual excesses in these films than they are by the sudden bursts of violence. In fact, the violence in "Basic Instinct 2" is kept to a minimum, most of it being seen after the actual act has taken place.  The sex, itself, is fairly graphic, although no more than what I would expect from such an undertaking.The plot of "Basic Instinct 2" follows Catherine from her old San Francisco stomping grounds to London Towne, at once picturesque and rainy, made all the more atmospheric by the stunningly photographed landmarks.  A soccer hero with whom Catherine is involved, dies in a questionable (and utterly tasteless) auto "accident" that opens the film. Drugs are found in the man's system, including one that induces paralysis, and the lead cop (David Thewliss) immediately suspects Catherine of murder.  Sent to criminal psychologist Michael Glass, Catherine wastes no time in weaving a web of lies and sexual intrigue that result in more deaths occurring before the unconvincing finale.The performances aren't bad, given the film's relentless silliness and determined lack of taste.  As stated, Stone has turned Catherine Tramell into a camp icon, a character who is, really, above criticism.  Love her or hate her, she is what she is. And she looks damn good, at age 48, doing what it is that she does so well.  As Glass, the psychologist with a painful past, David Morrissey does what he can with a role that varies wildly, requiring him to veer from stiff-upper-lip Britishness to out-of-his-gourd madman; the fact that his character is not remotely believable cannot be contributed to his lack of skill as an actor.  David Thewliss, as a good cop/bad cop combo starts out bringing a certain level of realism to his character, although once he goes over the top, there's no bringing him back.  And it's good to see Charlotte Rampling, as a colleague of Dr. Glass, back onscreen, even though she frequently looks like a deer caught in the headlights.  She seems unsure whether to maintain a certain dignity that seems to be in line the character she's playing, or to just let go and jump into the hammy fray.  Unfortunately (I think), by choosing the former and playing it safe, her performance is the one element that seems jarringly out of place in this free-for-all thriller.  In supporting roles, Indira Varma ("Rome") and Hugh Dancy, are scenic, but wasted, as ill-fated lovers who become ensnared in Catherine's web.While the film's plot just serves as an excuse to show us how clever Catherine is, with pretty, naked people assuming various sexual positions as violence pretty much consumes everyone onscreen, "Basic Instinct 2" is not without its merits.  To get the most of the movie, do not sit down to watch it with the intention of seeing a serious thriller; it's soft-core porn right down to its dark roots and twisted soul.  But if you know what you're in for, and don't take it too seriously, it's a hoot.

reviewText: "Basic Instinct 2: Risk Addiction" is a perfect example of why sequels should be outlawed. And especially sequels with returning actors, because they keep you from blotting the whole thing out of your memory.Though it took many years to formulate and approve the whole thing, "Basic Instinct 2" ends up being a messy, halfhearted effort that smacks of "direct to video." Except, sadly, it wasn't -- instead, it has been one of the most atrocious box office disasters of 2006 thus far. Both creatively and financially.Novelist Catherine Trammell (Sharon Stone, still trying to revive her career) is doing 110 mph while having sex. They splash off a bridge, and her soccer star lover dies. In the aftermath, a court shrink (David Morrisey) tries to determine if she is sane or not -- and ends up with the sultry killer salivating for him as her next victim/lover. Take this as a warning, guys: Practice safe sex. By that, I mean don't date a woman with risk addiction.Then the dead bodies start piling up around London, and it seems likely that Catherine is the culprit. Fascinated by Catherine, Glass soon becomes enmeshed as a murder suspect, and it means trouble for his ex wife and her boyfriend. Like Catherine's prior victims, the unwitting shrink is lured into a game of seduction and death.The plot is too similar to the original for there to be many surprises in "Basic Instinct 2," although it's rather interesting to relocate the action to London. And as this movie starts to wind up with a shrink and a car crash, it seems that it might actually be worth watching while sober.Then it deteriorates into a meandering waffle. Director Michael Caton-Jones obviously doesn't have the slightest idea where he should take this, so the movie just sort of ambles around aimlessly, getting more boring with every new scene. It almost resembles an arty French film.... except those don't have dialogue like "Don't take it so hard. Even Oedipus didn't see his mother coming." Ew.Don't expect sexpottiness from Stone in this movie: her performance here consists mainly of posing. Trammel is supposed to be smart, charming and witty -- and Stone shows none of this here. You'd think she'd at least TRY to act in her "comeback." Yes, she looks good for her age. But to justify a movie about a sultry killer, the sultry killer has to be more than a pretty picture.And David Morrisey gives a decent but pallid performance. The poor man looks utterly stupefied throughout the movie, and I can only assume that he's wondering how he signed on for this. A few other good actors -- Charlotte Rampling and Indira Varma among them -- appear, but don't really register."Basic Instinct 2: Risk Addiction" should have been light years better than it is, after a decade and a half of work on it. It may be a risk, but it's far from addicting.

reviewText: This is awful stuff but not for the obvious reasons. The most offensive aspect of this too-delinquent 2006 sequel to the 1992 box office hit is that it pretends to be a double-dip psychological thriller as well as yet another did-she-or-didn't-she sex crime story. Personally, I think there was great potential to turn this into a very black comedy about female empowerment, but the irony seems lost on the filmmakers. The net effect of all this heavy lifting in the plot is this enervating feeling that the movie will never end. The overly complicated screenplay by Leora Barish and Henry Bean is not the only culprit here, as Michael Caton-Jones' direction is pedestrian and plodding. Even the explicit sex scenes are captured in a rather clinical manner that generates nothing close to heat.The plot picks up crime novelist Catherine Tramell years (fourteen to be exact) after her San Francisco police troubles. Relocated to London, she gets implicated in the car crash death of her soccer player lover (she, of course, was driving). Enter police psychologist Dr. Michael Glass to assess her mental state, and the sexually oriented dangers from the first movie get recycled in this story. People start to get murdered. Inevitably, Glass gets painted into a corner, while Catherine keeps one step ahead of everyone else. It seems beside the point that Sharon Stone looks great for 47, though there is a surgical aura about her beauty (whether or not this is the case). Her nihilistic character has not been empowered by the intervening years but flattened into a one-note Machiavellian nymphomaniac, all knowing looks and come-ons with nary a trace of humanity. The fun in her performance has been deflated to fit the constant contrivances of the plot turns.She gets no help from her pasty-looking leading man, David Morrissey, who looks and sounds like the younger brother of Liam Neeson. He lacks the charisma and primal instincts to get away with Glass' quicksilver changes in behavior, especially in the sex scenes. The most inspired in-joke is placing the doctor's office in London's phallic-looking Swiss Re building. It seems a shame to recruit two world-class actors in supporting roles only to waste them - David Thewlis plays the suspicious police inspector, and Charlotte Rampling, looking spectacular at sixty (and a lesson in humility for Ms. Stone), as Glass' more seasoned colleague.Suffice it to say that the last five minutes are absurd to the extreme with no sense of viewer satisfaction over the conclusion. The journey from theaters to DVD has been an unsurprisingly fast one, and the disc includes Caton-Jones' rather bored commentary on an alternative track, and there are several deleted scenes all wisely excised. In fact, not enough was excised for my taste. There is also a disposable ten-minute making-of featurette where there is mention (or dare I say, the threat) of a "Basic Instinct 3".
summary: Desperately Joyless Sequel Misses Its Destiny as a Black Comedy

reviewText: Okay, I'll admit it, I greatly enjoyed this movie! His repression and slow burn anger at the box he must occupy both personally and professionally are brought over the edge by Trammell's complete relaxation with being off the leash.  He takes her on as a patient, having diagnosed her with the Hitchcockian sounding "Risk Addiction", and the movie focuses on their subsequent affair as the bodies start piling up around Dr. Glass.The movie revels in its over-the-top shenanigans.  It displays a kind of ramped up reality full of beautiful people, all decked out in high couture.  Stone has the best wardrobe here.  David Thewlis, as a foul-mouthed detective and Charlotte Rampling, as Glass' warm and wise mentor and colleague, and Hugh Dancy (Evening) as a shady tabloid reporter, add much class to the proceedings. The plot is easy to pull apart . . .example, even when Trammell is released for lack of evidence early on, wouldn't she still be charged with driving under the influence of narcotics? reviewText: Standing on it's own, BI2 is not a bad movie.  The problem lies in two aspects of the original; one, Michael Douglas' character was already on edge and unstable due to his shady dealings as a cop and his alcoholism.  Two; The famous leg crossing scene, there is nothing like it in BI2, but it's a good thing.  It allows the movie to stand on it's own more instead of relying on a gimmick.If Basic Instinct had never been made, this movie would stand out as a sexy, film noir thriller in which you have no idea who kills who.  Instead, we kind of feel like we're getting more of the same.  The main difference is Catherine Tramell, played again with steely confidence by Sharon Stone, has upped her stakes and decided to mess with the mind of a very stable, very grounded Psychoanalyst Michael Glass, played by David Morrissey (is `Glass' supposed to be euphemism for how fragile this guy is).  Once again she leads him on, manipulates those around him and makes him question everything he never questioned before.  The strange thing is, she meets him only because she is suspected of murder and a psych evaluation is ordered.  Glass is assigned to her.  This shows that her targets are picked on the fly (we know she's done this before) and this time picks a seemingly invulnerable target.  Glass has no vices, no shady past or skeletons in his closet and seems very capable of dealing with someone even as manipulative as Catherine.  However, she finds the weak points in his armor, mostly his `set of rules' and people in his personal life and slowly breaks down his psyche.Morrissey gives a great sliding-down-a-hill-into-the-wood-chipper performance.  There are many points where you can see him slipping away fast and you just want to grab him and say, `Get a hold of yourself, man!'.  David Thewlis is great as the Scotland Yard Detective of questionable ethics.  He plays his role just shy of over the top and gets away with it.  It's almost as if Stone and producers wanted to bring class and sophistication to the whole movie by setting it London.  And it works to a degree.  Stone certainly knows how to play her role, Catherine is bodacious, over the top, gaudy and sporting a potty mouth that would make sailors blush...but we love it.  And thankfully Stone still looks great after all these years at age 47 (with a little help from her Plastic Surgeon).  But it's been too long since the last one and we certainly don't want to see her do this kind of movie again after ANOTHER fourteen years.

reviewText: In 1992, director Paul Verhoven captiviated audiences with his bold, in-your-face approach to sex, murder, and mystery with his critically acclaimed, box office smash "Basic Instinct" starring Sharon Stone and Michael Douglas.  The movie was a huge success partly because it had so much controversy surrounding one of its key scenes, plus the sex appeal of the two lead actors guaranteed plenty of people wanting to see these two together on screen, but even without all that, the movie would have still succeeded because the story was so incredibly solid.  The creative forces behind the movie were smart enough to give people more than simply eye-candy, and offered up a twisted murder/mystery that would leave audiences guessing who the villain was until the very end.  After the films gigantic success, everyone knew there would be a sequel to continue the storyline, however all efforts to get this sequel off the ground failed miserably.  That is, until now, after years of struggle to get anything going with this possible franchise, Sharon Stone finally got to make the one sequel she was dying to make, "Basic Instinct 2"."Basic Instinct 2" (originally subtitled 'Risk Addiction') finds novelist Catherine Tramell (Sharon Stone) living in London, when she runs into legal trouble yet again when one of her lovers dies in a car accident that she was involved in.  With the London police desperately wanting to put Ms. Tramell behind bars, they call in criminal psychiatrist Michael Glass (David Morrissey) to evaluate her.  The question is, can Dr. Glass resist Catherine's sexual advances or will he fall prey to being another one of her victims?Even though Sharon Stone wanted desperately to make this movie, she really should have taken more time in reading the script before going in front of the camera.  The dialogue is not nearly as fluid as that of its predecessor, and the lines they give Sharon to spout as Catherine Tramell are just so stupid, and lack all of the subtle nuances and hints of malice that she had in the first film.  What was great about her character in the first movie, is that you never knew until the very last moment that she was guilty, and she was so seductive with her speech and body language that it was just enjoyable to watch, whereas in this movie she is basically raunchy and crude, with not a single hint of class that she had in the first movie.  The supporting cast is alright, though one does miss Michael Douglas, his character worked much better than David Morrissey's as a pawn in Catherine's web of seduction and murder.Another problem "Basic Instinct 2" ran into, was that they tried too hard to top "Basic Instinct" in terms of shock value.  The first movie had the infamous 'leg crossing scene', and contained so much sexuality that people were shocked by it.  However, with this movie being made 14 years later, people have been somewhat desensitized to sex, so the scenes are basically run-of-the-mill, and in some instances instead of being provocative, which is what they were going for, the scenes are somewhat disturbing which serves as a more of turn off to the film, rather than creating any interest in the movie.  It's sad to see that after 14 years of trying to get this movie made, and even having Sharon Stone sue the production company to force the movie to get a green-light, a move that should have raised a 'red flag' for her in terms of this movie's quality, this movie still comes off horrible, especially in comparison to its predecessor.  Another problem the movie had, is that since it took so long to make, Sharon is in all honesty just too old to be doing this type of role.  I mean there's no denying that at the age of 47 or 48, whichever she is, Sharon Stone is still sexy, but everyone knows that it's not her natural look anymore, and that there had to have been plenty of surgery to keep her looking the same way she did in the first film.  So really seeing her vamp it up, and doing the types of scenes required in a movie such as this, is somewhat creepy, when you think that this lady is almost 50 years old, a part of you screams out, "Move on to something more dramatic, and start acting your age", but that's just me.  You may have a different opinion, and maybe you can get past the age thing, but I still think that even if you could you'll still be disappointed because this film just lacks any kind of substance."Basic Instinct 2" is available in both Rated R and Unrated editions, both contain language, drug use, mild violence, and sexuality/nudity.

Many have suggested that this is the worst film of 2006 and I try hard to approach a viewing indifferent to such assertions.  After all, people hailed Crash as the best film of 2005 and I didn't buy into that hype.  I'm going with the sheep here though.  Basic Instinct 2 is the worst film of 2006.In a nutshell, we reconvene in London with Catherine Trammel as the film's protagonist.  Catherine is suspected of playing some role in the death of her boyfriend who was apparently drugged before a fatal car crash into the ocean.  After being released from the authorities she decides to hook up with a psychiatrist named Dr. Michael Glass (David Morrissey).  The mind games, sexual tension and murder ensue.The most important reason this film failed critically and only lasted about two weeks in American theaters is because of Sharon Stone's performance.  It really pains me to say that.  It is easy to target her age her but that is a slightly misguided criticism.  Sharon looks great for her late 40s in my opinion but her performance suggests a lack of confidence in her own ability to be as sexual as Trammel was in 1992.  First of all, it's not an easy task to duplicate that performance in the first place, but Stone's failure might expose her as a one-dimensional actress recycling a role she is no longer capable of delivering.  It's not her looks that are not sexy; it's her attitude and her paper thin performance that lacks the confidence to be even remotely compelling.  I would even propose that her performance affected the confidence of everyone working this film.  It's entirely possible that the success of the movie depended on Sharon Stone almost exclusively.  Being a huge fan of the first movie, I sincerely wanted her to pull it off.  To Stone's credit, the task at hand was a difficult one.Basic Instinct 2 also doesn't contain nearly the edge that the first film did.  That isn't to say it was necessary to do so.  In fact, some aspects of the first film could certainly be deemed gratuitous and this sequel is notably missing the copious amounts of nudity that the first film contained, for better or worse.  Perhaps there was a conscious effort to be less gratuitous and there is of course some merit to that attempt.  But they failed in not being gratuitous as well because the dialogue in this sequel is at times unnecessarily filthy.  In fact, it seemed like someone intentional added sexual references to the end of some sentences just for the hell of it.  The dialogue was also laughably bad at times and the actors of course struggled in delivering some lines convincingly.The other big flaw is the story in general.  It's not horrible, it's just too convoluted and the movie really dragged at times.  To be blunt, it was really boring for the most part and just didn't hook me in.  I love to recognize notoriously bad films that hook me in just for being so poor; like Mac and Me, Dungeons and Dragons, Plan 9 From Outer Space or Manos, but Basic Instinct 2 isn't even as memorable.  It's bad like Gigli or Death to Smoochy was bad.  It is forgetfully bad.  I almost had to take notes just to recall some key points for this review.

reviewText: The reason the original "Basic Instinct" stands out in my mind is not because of Sharon Stone's infamous interrogation scene, or the bit with the ice pick under the bed.  I remember it because the 1992 film represented to me the end of an era defined by the O.J. Simpson trial, and today epitomized by the myriad "C.S.I." television shows.  "Basic Instinct" begins with the murder of Johnny Boz, a rock and roll star who is stabbed with an ice pick in bed after a night of torrid sex.  His girlfriend, Catherine Tramell (Sharon Stone), is a prime suspect but the police are unable to connect her with the crime.  Now, keep in mind that at the murder scene the bed is fairly soaked with at least three different types of bodily fluids, of which one is not going to be the victim's.  A good crime lab and the case is solved, but this was not that type of movie and its sequel is required to be in a similar vein.The problem with making a sequel to "Basic Instinct" is that faced by any effort to have lightning strike twice.  You have to do it again but do it differently, a fine line to try and walk.  Actually, the script by Leora Barish ("Desperately Seeking Susan) and Henry Bean ("Internal Affairs") come up with something that does the job, the only problem is you are not aware of this until the movie is over and you have to rethink everything you have just seen.  This creates a new problem, in that you actually have to watch this movie twice to determine how good it is because nobody is going to be able to judge retroactively if they pulled it off the first time you watch the film.  This is a significant problem because there are people who are not going to want to see "Basic Instinct 2" once, let alone twice.You watch this 2006 film knowing that you have take everything Catherine says and does as being part of her plan.  The question is what is the plan.  We are in London and Catherine is out enjoying her only peculiar brand of auto-erotica, when the guy ends up dead.  Inspector Roy Washburn (David Thewlis) does not buy the innocent act and wants her head.  The court orders her to undergo a psychological evaluation by Michael Glass (David Morrissey), who tells the world Catherine is suffering, for lack of a better word, from risk addiction and that things will only get worse.  He means that she will end up dead, but of course it is other people who start ending up corpses, but not until the film requires us to suspend our disbelief to make the plot work.  This is when Catherine becomes Michael's patient.Now, this is wrong on so many levels, but without it the story is not going to work so you have to just shake your head and go on.  Even knowing what she is much better than most, Michael becomes obsessed with her, while she toys with him in just about every way possible.  He is doomed and it is just a question of how Catherine wants to bring him down, although you are right to pay attention to the nagging voice that tells you there has to be more to it than that.  It is just that this guy has no chance against Catherine, even if he has Washburn and super shrink Milena Gardosh (Charlotte Rampling) on his side.  This is mostly because of the characters and certainly because of the writing, but also because where as Michael Douglas could sort of catch up with Sharon Stone, I never believe that David Morrissey has a chance.Stone looks great, and not just when she is naked, because what stands out in this performance is her eyes (I keep thinking "shark" eyes, but that might be underestimating the situation) and the way that makes her dirty talk such an effective sexual come on (it is not easy, but do not try it at home because I do not want to be responsible for disasters of an intimate nature).  I was almost going to round up on "Basic Instinct 2," because I did go back and watch it a second time to see how it reads once you know what is "really" going on (and they were right not to go with the alternate ending because the more subtle approach preserves the requisite sense of ambiguity).  On balance, I think the alternative reading works more than it does not, but there are a couple of points where they play it too far the other way to make sure we buy into it the way they want to set up the final revelation.  Given the circumstances of the sequel, the script is certainly ambitious, but without a co-star on the same level as Stone in the final analysis "Basic Instinct 2" just cannot carry it off.
summary: They came up with a decent story of the sequel, but Sharon Stone neeeded a stronger co-star

reviewText: Many critics have made it their life's work to denigrate this movie; and let's face it, any film that costs $70 million to make and then only brings in $6 million (in the USA) must indeed have some serious shortcomings: Sharon Stone was reportedly paid $14 million to appear, and then turns in a performance that ranges from riveting to absurd. The duplicity of the plot is already well known...there are no real surprises. The male lead (David Morrisey) is a limp noodle when compared to Michael Douglas. It is a sequel, and all sequels (except Godfather II) stink, etc. etc.....BUT, in defense of this much-maligned psychological pot boiler, it should be noted that it definitely has its good moments, and is, in the end, rather thought provoking.Sharon Stone plays her signature role with the gusto of a female carnivore devouring its young. Granted, at times her mugging and menacing get a little tiresome, but I can't picture another actress playing the role any better, except (after seeing the movie "Unfaithful") maybe Diane Lane. In between the scenery chewing, she generates some serious electricity. Even at 47 years old, her appearance in the hot tub scene will reacquaint you with the "slow motion" and "step" buttons on your DVD remote. Yes indeed, the magic smile is even effective under water. No one on earth can convey irresistible, compellingly attractive evil more effectively, simply with her eyes, a smile, a look, or a suggestive remark. As Catherine Tramell, she is completely up front about her perverse intentions, there is no sneakiness or guile, and she performs her evil magic right before the eyes of her prey, daring him/her to resist....or so it seems....for this is the second redeeming feature of the movie: the plot, though similar to its first iteration, is actually quite clever and intricately woven. You could have a lengthy and inconclusive debate over the identity of the actual villain. If you watch the movie twice (granted, many detractors would say this is impossible), no mistakes are made. Even in The Usual Suspects, a masterpiece of misdirection, a concrete conclusion is provided. Not so in this story, which for some may be a maddening cop-out, but to me is both unique and stimulating.In conclusion, you have been thoroughly warned about the downsides of this cinematic punching bag....yes there are some weak, even absurd moments, but I assure you that there are also some intense, stimulating, entertaining, and memorable moments to compensate you for your time, and, let's face it, this is more than you can say about a lot of movies.

reviewText: From Triniman's Blog, Blogcritics and Desicritics.This film will draw in a lot of people looking for a sexy murder-mystery thriller.  Basic Instinct 2 delivers instead a very poor imitation of the original from 14 years ago.Author Catherine Tramell survives her car crashing into the water, but her male companion dies in the process, apparently drugged earlier that evening to be slow, sluggish and have his lungs fail.  In order to figure out if she's a danger to herself or the public, the court appoints a psychiatrist, Dr. Michael Glass (David Morrissey) to evaluate her.  Soon after, people around him begin to drop like flies.  There are signs that point to Tramell as the killer but the victims also appear to be people the psychiatrist could have killed, for his own personal reasons.You know the film is about to fall apart when the psychiatrist declares that he doesn't socialize with his patients.  Surprise, surprise, guess who breaks his own rule not too long after?  Is there anyone, man or woman, who can resist her?  Apparently, not.Sharon Stone (47) was actually really good as the rich, playgirl author, who never seems to be living in the real world.  She appears to be somewhat loopy and carefree, never serious for even a second, confident that she is the ruler of her existence.  She gets what she wants and people are magnetically seduced by her.  Still, we don't get to know her character very much. We don't get inside her head except when we find out in court what Dr. Glass believes about her personality flaws. She's also given some pretty stupid dialogue.David Morrissey isn't as watchable as Michael Douglas, cop Nick Curran, from the first film.  The electricity between them just isn't there.  I wonder how much better it could have been with Clive Owen instead.  His screen precence is much stronger.  He isn't helped, however, by the film's weakly executed story.David Thewlis, last seen in the third Harry Potter movie as Professor Lupin, also doesn't put in a great performance as the detective with an apparent dirty past, on the trail of Tramell.  Veteran actress Charlotte Rampling also seemed underused as psychiatrist Milena Gardosh, a minor role in the film.  I kept waiting on her character to be a more significant player but that didn't happen.This could have been a better film, if there was more of detective story to it with more intrigue and focus.  Audiences prefer murder mysteries to be more about "who-dunnit" with "a-ha" moments, rather than just a parade of corpses and a lead character constantly being sexually gratified.  Director Michael Caton-Jones has had better success with The Jackal and Rob Roy.My rating for this film is 2/5 and I wouldn't see it again.
